text: Hello everyone. Welcome back to Speak English Daily. I'm Emma and I'm so happy you're here with me today. And today I
have a very special challenge for you.
Right now I want you to close your eyes.
Yes, close your eyes. And I want you to try something.
Try to tell me about your day yesterday in English for just two minutes. Don't stop talking. Don't pause. Just keep
speaking about what you did yesterday.
How did that feel? Did you struggle? Did you repeat the same words over and over?
Did you feel stuck? Don't worry. This is completely normal.
And today, I'm going to change that forever.
By the end of this onehour podcast, you will be able to talk about your entire day in English fluently, confidently, and naturally.
You'll have the vocabulary, the rhythm, and most importantly, the confidence to speak English without thinking. We're going to spend one hour
living in English together.
When you master daily routine chunks, you're actually mastering the building blocks of all English conversation.
I know 60 minutes sounds like a long time, but think about it. You probably spend 60 minutes every day scrolling social media, watching TV, or doing
other activities that don't improve your life. Today, invest those 60 minutes in yourself, in your English, in your future.
This is not like other English lessons.
This is a real experience.
We're going to live a full day together and you're going to shadow me. Repeat after me. Every single step of the way.
Let me tell you why this method is so powerful. For 10 years, I've taught thousands of students from over 50 countries. And I discovered something
amazing.
Students who could describe their daily routine perfectly were the ones who became fluent fastest.
Why? Because daily routine vocabulary is the foundation of all English conversation.
Think about it. When you meet someone new, what do you talk about? Your work, your family, your hobbies, your daily
life. When you have a job interview, what do they ask? Tell me about yourself.
When you call customer service, what do you need to explain? your problem, your situation, your daily experience.
But here's the secret. Most English teachers don't tell you. Your brain learns languages through patterns, not rules. When you memorize grammar
rules, you're using your slow, analytical brain. But when you practice real situations over and over, you're training your fast automatic brain, the
same part that native speakers use.
Now, let me explain how this podcast works.
This is not a normal English lesson where you sit and listen passively.
This is active training for your mouth, your ears, and your brain.
Shadowing means you repeat everything I say at the same time I'm saying it.
Think of it like singing along to your favorite song. You don't wait for the song to finish. You sing with the music.
That's exactly what we're doing with English.
Don't worry about being perfect. Don't worry about your accent.
Don't worry about making mistakes.
Native speakers make mistakes, too. What matters is training your mouth muscles and your brain to work together automatically.
Here's how to do it. Listen to my voice.
Feel the rhythm. Notice when I pause.
Notice when I go up or down in tone, then speak with me. If you miss a word, don't stop. Just jump back in with the
next word. Keep going. Keep flowing.
Keep speaking. You can do this anywhere. walking, cooking, cleaning, exercising.
In fact, moving your body while speaking actually helps your brain learn faster.
Many of my students listen while walking their dogs, doing dishes, or commuting to work. Professional language researchers call this comprehensible
input with active output. But I call it learning English the way babies learn by copying, repeating, and gradually becoming natural.
The most important thing is comfort. Get your favorite drink. Find a comfortable place and relax.
Most English learners try to learn everything at once. business English, academic English, slang, idioms, but they can't order food confidently.
They can't describe their weekend plans.
They can't explain their job to a new friend. They're trying to build a house without a foundation.
Today, we're building your foundation.
We're giving you the core vocabulary and sentence patterns that every fluent English speaker uses automatically.
Once you have this foundation, everything else becomes easier.
Speak with me and transform your English today. If yes, let's begin this incredible journey together. Don't worry
about your accent. Just relax, listen, and repeat after me. Get your tea, coffee, or water. Find a comfy spot, and let's start our English adventure
together. Let's begin at the very beginning.
Morning time. I'll tell you about my morning and you can practice with me.
Every morning I wake up at 7:00.
I stretch my arms and say, "Good morning, world.
Then I get out of bed and start my day.
First, I go to the bathroom.
I brush my teeth for 2 minutes.
Brushing teeth is so important.
I wash my face with cold water.
Cold water really wakes me up.
Then I go to the kitchen. I make my first coffee of the day.
I love coffee so much. I also drink a glass of water because water is good for you.
For breakfast, I usually have toast with butter.
Sometimes I add strawberry jam.
Strawberry jam is my favorite.
A simple breakfast gives me energy for the day. What about you?
When do you wake up? What do you eat for breakfast?
You can practice saying, "I wake up at 8:00.
I eat cereal for breakfast." Or, "I drink orange juice in the morning." Let me tell you more about breakfast options.
Some people eat eggs, scrambled eggs, fried eggs, or boiled eggs.
Some people prefer oatmeal with fruit.
Others like yogurt with honey. Some people, like my brother, eat leftover pizza for breakfast.
That's a bit unusual.
But hey, food is food.
After breakfast, it's time to get dressed. Getting ready is important. I go to my bedroom and open my closet.
Today, I choose a blue shirt because blue is a nice color that goes with everything. I put on my favorite black pants. Black is so versatile.
Now, for shoes, I have many different shoes.
Running shoes for exercise, dress shoes for work, casual shoes for shopping.
Today, I choose my comfortable white sneakers because I'll be walking a lot. I look in the mirror and comb my hair. Looking good gives me confidence.
I grab my bag and check inside. Phone, wallet, keys, everything is here, so I'm ready to go.
What clothes do you like wearing? Do you prefer shirts or t-shirts, jeans or dress pants? What's your favorite color to wear? You can say, "I
like wearing blue jeans. My favorite shirt is red." Or, "I always wear comfortable shoes." Some people love fashion and have many different outfits.
Others prefer simple clothes in basic colors. My friend Sarah changes her style every season, but I stick to what
I know looks good on me. Comfort is most important.
Now I'm ready to leave my house.
Time to face the world.
I lock my door and walk to the bus stop.
The bus stop is on Main Street where many people are waiting. We all need to go to work, school, or shopping. The bus
arrives right on time. It's red and white with big windows.
I get on the bus and show my ticket to the friendly driver. Good morning, I say, and he smiles back.
I find a seat by the window where I can see the city.
There are tall buildings, busy cars, and windows and people walking on the sidewalks.
Everyone is starting their day just like me. The city is full of energy in the morning.
How do you travel every day?
Do you take the bus like me? Maybe you drive your own car or walk or ride a bicycle.
Some people take the subway or the train. In big cities, there are many transportation options.
I love watching people during my bus ride. There's a man reading a newspaper, a woman listening to music with headphones,
and a student studying for an exam.
Everyone has their own story, their own destination.
The bus connects all of us together on our daily journeys.
The traffic is always heavy in the morning.
Cars, trucks, motorcycles, and buses all share the road. Traffic lights change from red to green to yellow.
Pedestrians wait at crosswalks.
It's like a big organized dance that happens every single day.
Now I arrive at the community center where I work.
Time to start my day helping people learn English.
I say hello to my colleagues in the hallway. Good morning everyone.
They smile and say hello back.
I work with wonderful people who are all passionate about education and helping newcomers to our country.
I go to my classroom and put the chairs in a circle.
Today I teach English to new people in our city.
They come from different countries.
Japan, Korea, Bangladesh, and Thailand. Each person has a story. Each person has dreams for their new life here.
My first student comes early. Good morning, teacher Emma, says Yuki from Japan.
Good morning, Yuki. How are you today? I ask.
I am good, thank you, she says with a smile.
I love watching my students learn.
Yuki could only say hello when she started 6 months ago.
At 9:00, all 10 students are here.
We start with easy conversation.
What did you do yesterday? I ask.
Minjun from Korea raises his hand. I went to the store. I bought apples.
Everyone claps.
We are happy for every small success in our classroom.
Today we learn about shopping.
My students need to buy food and clothes. We practice simple phrases.
How much is this?
Where is the milk? Thank you very much.
We practice together and I help them feel confident.
My students are very brave. They left their home countries. They left their families and friends.
Now they must learn English to live here.
English is not just words for them.
English helps them buy food, find jobs, and make friends. At lunchtime, I finish my morning work.
I say goodbye to my students. See you tomorrow, I tell them.
See you tomorrow, teacher Emma, they say back.
I feel happy when I help people learn English.
The morning is busy with teaching and helping students.
I love my job because I can see students grow every day.
Teaching English is not just work for me.
It is my passion.
Lunchtime is my favorite time of the day.
Time to eat something delicious.
Today I want to try a new restaurant called Sunny Kitchen.
The name sounds cheerful and inviting.
I walk inside and the waiter greets me with a big smile.
Welcome. Table for one, he asks.
Yes, please, I reply.
He shows me to a nice table by the window where I can watch people walking by.
The menu has so many choices.
Soup, salad, pasta, pizza, chicken, fish, vegetarian options.
Everything looks delicious.
The waiter returns to take my order.
Are you ready? He asks.
Yes, I'd like the grilled chicken sandwich with a side salad and a fresh lemonade, please.
Excellent choice, he says. The chicken is our specialty today.
While I wait for my food, I look around the restaurant.
The atmosphere is warm and friendly.
There are families with children, business people having lunch meetings, and couples enjoying romantic meals together.
Food brings everyone together.
What's your favorite type of food? Do you like Italian food like pizza and pasta?
Maybe you prefer Asian food like sushi or curry.
Or perhaps you love simple comfort food like burgers and fries.
My food arrives and it looks amazing.
The chicken is perfectly grilled. The salad is fresh and crisp and the lemonade is cold and sweet.
I eat slowly and enjoy every bite. Good food makes me happy and gives me energy for the afternoon.
Some people eat lunch at their desk while working, but I prefer to take a real break.
Stepping away from work helps me relax and return with fresh energy and new ideas.
After lunch, I need to buy some groceries.
Let's go shopping together.
I walk to the supermarket down the street.
It's a big store with everything you could need. Food, drinks, cleaning supplies, personal care items. I take a shopping cart and start my journey
through the aisles.
First stop, the produce section. The fruits and vegetables look so fresh and colorful.
I pick five red apples, some bananas for snacks, and a bag of salad greens.
The tomatoes smell wonderful, so I choose three of them. Next, the dairy section. I need milk for my morning coffee, some cheese for sandwiches,
and yogurt for healthy snacks.
The refrigerated section keeps everything perfectly cold and fresh.
In the bakery area, the smell of fresh bread is incredible.
I choose a loaf of whole wheat bread.
It's healthier than white bread and tastes better, too.
The baker tells me it was made this morning.
Do you enjoy grocery shopping?
Some people love it. Others find it boring.
I actually like walking through the store and discovering new products.
It's like a treasure hunt for good food.
The checkout line moves quickly today.
The cashier is friendly and efficient.
Did you find everything you needed? she asks.
"Yes, thank you," I reply.
I pay with my credit card and pack my groceries in reusable bags. Better for the environment.
Shopping is a necessary part of life, but it can also be enjoyable when you're not in a hurry.
I like to read labels, compare prices, and sometimes try new brands or flavors.
After shopping, I meet my friend Sarah for coffee.
This is the best part of my day.
Sarah is already waiting at our favorite cafe, The Daily Grind.
She waves when she sees me approaching.
"Hi, Emma. Perfect timing," she says with a big smile.
We hug like we haven't seen each other in months, even though it was just last week. We order our usual drinks.
Sarah gets a cappuccino with extra foam, and I get a caramel latte.
The barista knows us well and always makes our coffee exactly how we like it.
The cafe is cozy with soft music, comfortable chairs, and the wonderful smell of fresh coffee beans.
So, tell me about your week, Sarah says as we sit down.
I share stories about work, funny things that happened and my plans for the weekend.
Sarah tells me about her new cooking class, and the delicious pasta she learned to make.
We talk about everything.
Movies we want to see, books we're reading, places we want to travel.
Did you hear about that new comedy at the cinema? Sarah asks.
Not yet. Is it funny? I reply.
Hilarious. We should go see it this weekend.
Good friends are so precious.
They make life richer and more meaningful. With Sarah, I can be completely myself.
We laugh together, support each other through difficult times, and celebrate each other's successes.
Do you have a best friend like Sarah?
What do you like to do together?
Maybe you go to movies, play sports, cook together, or just talk for hours.
Friendship is one of life's greatest gifts.
We spend almost an hour just talking and enjoying each other's company.
Time flies when you're with good friends.
Finally, we have to leave. Same time next week, Sarah asks. Absolutely, I reply.
We hug goodbye and promise to call each other soon.
Now I'm home and it's time to relax after a busy day.
I change into my most comfortable clothes, soft sweatpants and a cozy sweater.
Comfort is so important at the end of the day. I put my work clothes away and let my shoulders relax.
I'm a little hungry, so I make a simple dinner.
Tonight, it's pasta with tomato sauce and a sprinkle of Parmesan cheese.
Simple food can be the most satisfying.
While the pasta cooks, I prepare a small salad with the vegetables I bought earlier.
I eat dinner while watching the evening news.
The weather forecast says tomorrow will be sunny. That makes me smile.
There are stories about local events, sports scores, and interesting human interest stories from around the world.
After dinner, I wash the dishes and tidy up the kitchen.
A clean space helps me feel peaceful and organized.
I like ending the day with everything in its proper place.
How do you like to spend your evenings?
Some people watch TV, others read books, play games, or talk with family.
Everyone has their own way of unwinding after work.
Now comes my favorite evening activity.
Working on my YouTube channel, Speak English Daily.
I go to my home office and turn on my computer.
The screen lights up with hundreds of comments from students around the world.
I start reading the comments from my videos such as that is great to improve my English listening skill and thank this channel is outstanding
easily understood by learners and one that simply says no words excellent.

They remind me why I love doing this work.

I spend time replying to the comments.
Thank you so much. Keep practicing every day.
I'm glad this video helped you.
Each comment gets a personal response because I care about every single student.
Through these comments, I learn about the problems my students face.
Many struggle with pronunciation.
Others feel nervous speaking to strangers.
Some have trouble with job interviews.
Every comment teaches me something new about what my students need.
I open my notebook and start planning tomorrow's video.

I start recording my new video. Hello everyone. Welcome back to Speak English Daily. I'm Emma and today we're going to

The evening light coming through my window is soft and golden.

Creating content that helps people learn English fills me with purpose and joy.
It's my mom calling. "Hi, Mom," I answer cheerfully. "Hello, sweetheart. How was your day?" she asks in her warm, caring
voice. "It was wonderful. I had lunch at a new restaurant and met Sarah for coffee.
How are you and dad?" We're doing great.
Your father's in the garden watering his tomato plants.

Your favorite.
Mom always knows how to make me smile.
Save some for me. I laugh.
We talk about family news. My cousin got a new job. My aunt is planning a vacation. and my little nephew learned to ride a bicycle.
Family updates always make me feel connected to everyone, even when we live far apart.
Are you eating well? Getting enough sleep?
Mom asks. She always worries about me.
Yes, mom. I'm taking good care of myself. I promise.
Good. You know, I worry about you living alone in the big city.
Family relationships are so important.
Even though I'm an adult with my own life, my parents still care about me every single day.
Their love gives me strength and confidence.
We talk for about 20 minutes before saying goodbye.
Call us this weekend. Mom says, "I will give Dad my love." I will, sweetheart. Sleep well. Good night, Mom. Love you.
These conversations with family always make my day complete.
Before bed, I always like to plan the next day. Organization helps me feel prepared and confident.
I get my planner and look at tomorrow's schedule.
9:00 team meeting about the new project.
I need to review my notes and prepare some questions.
10:30 dentist appointment for my regular cleaning.
Not fun, but necessary for healthy teeth.
12:00 lunch with my sister Jessica.
We're going to try that new Italian restaurant downtown.
I'm excited to spend time with her and hear about her new apartment.
3:00 grocery shopping again.
I need ingredients for Sunday dinner with my parents.
Mom gave me her recipe for chicken parmesan and I want to make it perfectly.
6:00 yoga class at the community center.
Exercise is so important for both physical and mental health.
Yoga helps me stretch, relax, and clear my mind after busy days. Good planning makes everything easier.
When I know what to expect, I feel less stressed and more in control.
I can prepare mentally for each activity and make sure I have everything I need.
I also write down three goals for tomorrow, finish the monthly report, call my college friend who lives in another city, and water my house plants.
Small goals help me stay productive and organized.
Do you plan your days in advance?
Some people prefer to be spontaneous, but I like having a structure. It helps me balance work, family, friends, and personal time effectively.
The day is ending and it's time to prepare for sleep. A good bedtime routine helps me relax completely.
First, I brush my teeth thoroughly with mint toothpaste.
Clean teeth are so important for health and confidence.
I floss, too. My dentist would be proud.
I wash my face with warm water and apply moisturizer to keep my skin soft.
I put on my favorite pajamas.
They're light blue with little stars.
Comfortable sleepwear makes such a difference for good sleep. I set my alarm clock for 7:00 tomorrow morning, giving me plenty of time to wake up
slowly. I turn off all the electronic devices.
No more phone, TV, or computer. The blue light from screens can make it harder to fall asleep. Instead, I dim the lights
and create a peaceful atmosphere.
I spend a few minutes writing in my gratitude journal. Today, I'm grateful for good food, time with Sarah, my mom's phone call, and feeling healthy and
strong. Focusing on positive things helps me end the day with a happy heart.
I get into bed and pull up my soft blankets.
The sheets are clean and cool against my skin. I take three deep breaths in through my nose, out through my mouth.
My body starts to relax completely.
What do you do before bed?
Some people read, others listen to soft music or practice meditation.
Everyone needs their own special way to transition from day to night, from being awake to being asleep.
I think about the good moments from today and smile.
Tomorrow will bring new experiences, new conversations, and new opportunities to practice English.
As I close my eyes, my mind begins to wander into the world of dreams.
Sometimes I dream about traveling to beautiful places. I might be walking on a sunny beach with white sand and blue
water or hiking through green mountains with fresh clean air.
In my dreams, I can go anywhere in the world. Other times I dream about people I love. My family, my friends, even
colleagues from work. We might be having dinner together, laughing at funny stories, or celebrating special occasions.
Dreams often bring back happy memories from the past.
Dreams are mysterious and wonderful.
Scientists say we need dreams for our mental health. Dreams help our brains process the day's experiences and prepare for tomorrow's challenges.
Good sleep is essential for everything. our physical health, our emotional well-being, our ability to think clearly and make good decisions.
8 hours of sleep helps our bodies repair and our minds recharge.
Sleep is not wasted time. It's productive time when our bodies and minds do important work. Tomorrow I'll wake up refreshed,
energized, and ready for another beautiful day of living life in English.
And so our perfect English day comes to an end.
